characters: INTERIOR T.V. CONTROL ROOM ON STAGE
INTERIOR T.V. THEATRE NEAR STAGE DOOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP on RINGO. He is eating a bone dry sandwich that  curls up at the end. He puts it down with disgust. He has lager glass in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (accusingly) That was fresh this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We now see the pub is full of enormous cockney workmen do pints. RINGO is very much alone. He moves away from the bar towa a group that is standing together, they've an average hei of over six-foot. There is a group at a dart board. Another group is playin bar skittles and a third group is around a pin-ball table Near the bar is a shove-halfpenny board with two players. There is a caged parrot nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ringo) That'll be two and nine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RINGO fumbles some change out of his pocket. A few copper fall from his hand on to the shove-halfpenny board just a the crucial point has been made. The men glare at him.  Embarrassed, he moves away and without looking, places hi glass on the skittles table just as a player swings the  string, which hits Ringo's glass. More embarrassed, RINGO backs away, unfortunately into the pin-table just as a wi score is about to be reached. He bumps it very slightly, enough to cause it to TILT. He then moves to the dart boa By this time most of the pub is staring at him. With grea style he takes the darts. The first throw goes into a che sandwich which a man is pointing in demonstration. The second we see arrive into a pint of bitter and then w see RINGO shoot the third dart and hear the sound of the  parrot shouting angrily, off. The BARMAID has had enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right... On your way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard, on your way, troublemaker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the centre of attention, RINGO backs out of the pub,  followed by every eye in the place, the BARMAID and a few players following him to the door...

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR STREET OUTSIDE PUB
dialogues.text: RINGO comes out and crosses road, watched by the POLICEMA who is now quite suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR STREET
dialogues.text: PAUL comes down the street looking about him for RINGO. I the street is an old building, the sort of place that is  highly favoured for TV rehearsals. There is a sign on the door, "TV Rehearsal Room." As PAUL draws near, a load of  actors and extras, etc. are leaving, they are in costume, they are the ones who earlier had been going to a word  rehearsal. When PAUL gets near the entrance he decides to inside.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR HALL
dialogues.text: PAUL enters and wanders about. He reaches a door, pushes open and looks in. He sees a GIRL clad in period costume. She is moving around the room and obviously acting. PAUL  watches her for a moment and then decides to go in.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR REHEARSAL ROOM
dialogues.text: PAUL goes into the room. The GIRL is in mid-flight. She i very young and lovely and completely engrossed in what sh is doing. The room is absolutely empty except for PAUL an herself. She is acting in the manner of an eighteenth-cen coquette, or, to be precise, the voice English actresses when they think they are being true to the costume period her youth however makes it all very charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I believed you, sir, I might do  those things and walk those ways  only to find myself on Problem's  Path. But I cannot believe you, and  all those urgings serve only as a  proof that you will lie and lie again  to gain your purpose with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She dances lightly away from an imaginary lover and as sh turns she sees PAUL who is as engrossed in the scene as s was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enthusiastically) Well... go 'head, do the next bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away! You've spoilt it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry I spoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes no attempt to go. He simply continues to look  steadily at the girl; then he smiles at her. She is undec what to do next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you supposed to be here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got you worried, haven't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm warning you, they'll be back in  a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'you know something, "They" don't  worry me at all. Anyroad, I only  fancy listening to you... that's all  but if it worries you... well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're from Liverpool, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ironically) How'd you guess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seriously) Oh, it's the way you talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (innocently) Is it... is it, really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspiciously) Are you pulling my leg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking her straight  in the eye) Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unsure) I see. (airily) Do you like the play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... I mean, sure, well, I took  it at school but I only ever heard  boys and masters saying those lines,  like, sounds different on a girl. (smiles to himself) Yeah, it's gear on a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, the big hammer, smashing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mench... well, why don't you  give us a few more lines, like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIRL pouts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't half slam the door in  people's faces, do you? I mean, what  about when you're playing the part,  like, hundreds of people'll see you  and ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in) I'm not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're the understudy, sort of  thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (aggressively) I'm a walk-on in a fancy dress scene.  I just felt like doing those lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see. You are an actress though,  aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, I knew you were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the way you were spouting,  like.... (he imitates her) "I don't believe you, sir..." and  all that. Yeah, it was gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) The big hammer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Oh aye, a sledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the way you did it then sounded  so phony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... I wouldn't say that... just  like an actress... you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves and stands about like an actress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's not like a real person at  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye well, actresses aren't like real  people, are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ought to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know, anyroad up, they  never are, are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasingly) What are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in a group... well... there are  four of us, we play and sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you don't sound like real  people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do, you know. We sound like us  having a ball. It's fab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it really fab or are you just  saying that to convince yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What of? Look, I wouldn't do it unless  I was. I'm dead lucky 'cos I get  paid for doing something I love doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs and with a gesture takes in the whole studio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...all this and a jam butty too!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only enjoy acting for myself. I  hate it when other people are let  in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? I mean, which are you, scared  or selfish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why selfish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you've got to have people to  taste your treacle toffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, hang on, I've not gone daft. You  see, when I was little me mother let  me make some treacle toffee one time  in our back scullery. When I'd done  she said to me, "Go and give some to  the other kids." So, I said I would  but I thought to meself, "She must  think I'm soft." Anyroad, I was eating  away there but I wanted somebody  else to know how good it was so in  the end I wound up giving it all  away... but I didn't mind, mind,  'cos I'd made the stuff in the first  place. Well... that's why you need  other people... an audience... to  taste your treacle toffee, like.  Eh... does that sound as thickheaded  to you as it does to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really but I'm probably not a  toffee maker. How would you do those  lines of mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, look at it this way, I mean,  when you come right down to it, that  girl, she's a bit of a scrubber,  isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course... Look, if she was a  Liverpool scrubber... (Paul starts acting a  Liverpool girl, he  minces about then  turns, extending his  leg) Eh, fella, you want to try pulling  the other one, it's got a full set  of bells hanging off it... Y'what?...  I know your sort, two cokes and a  packet of cheese and onion crisps  and suddenly it's love and we're  stopping in an empty shop doorway.  You're just after me body and y'can't  have it... so there!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shattered) And you honestly think that's what  she meant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, definitely, it sticks out a mile,  she's trying to get him to marry her  but he doesn't want... well... I  don't reckon any fella's ever wanted  to get married. But girls are like  that, clever and cunning. You've got  to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's nice to know you think  we're clever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) And cunning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you do about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Oh, I don't have the time, I'm  always running about with the lads...  no, we don't have the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not noticing the  invitation) Aye, it is but as long as you get  by, it's all right, you know... bash  on, happy valley's when they let you  stop. Anyroad, I'd better get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going) See you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAUL stands at the doorway, shrugs then goes out.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR STREET
dialogues.text: In the street, workmen are collecting shovels, drinking t and doing all the things people do around building sites. RINGO mooches around. In the road is a hole with a diameter of about 3 feet, an at least 6 feet deep. RINGO looks down and a man is busil working at the bottom of the hole. He glares at RINGO. Af a moment RINGO turns away. We now see a very elegant youn lady coming towards RINGO. She is daintily avoiding a ser of puddles. RINGO has an idea and does a Sir Walter Ralei with his large Mac spreading it over one of the puddles. girl walks across it smiling graciously. RINGO proceeds w the coat to the next puddle and to the next backing gradu towards the hole. At last he spreads the coat, without noticing what he is  doing, over the hole. The girl steps onto the coat and  disappears sharply. RINGO looks down the hole where the g is held in the workman's arms. The workman rises out of t manhole until he is waist height. At this point an elegan dressed gentleman appears (the girl's husband) he looks a his wife in the workman's arms and hits the workman. RING backs away through the puddles, and is nicked by the  POLICEMAN. [Scenes 75 and 76 deleted in revision.]

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR T.V. THEATRE NEAR STAGE DOOR
dialogues.text: The DIRECTOR is pacing up and down the corridor. NORM is  also walking up and down, SHAKE is leaning against the wa quite unconcerned. NORM gives SHAKE a push.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worry, will you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHAKE adjusts his features to a worrying expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Well, that's it, two minutes to the  final run-through... they're bound  to miss it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll murder that Lennon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I suppose we can survive a missed  run-through as long...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as they head up for the show. Oh  yes, well I mean it'ud be a pity to  miss the show, wouldn't it like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shurrup, cheerful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horrible prospect hits the DIRECTOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reassuring him) They'll be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh now, they can't do that to me. (turning on Norm) It's all your fault. (overriding Norm) Oh yes it is and if they don't turn  up I wouldn't be in your shoes for  all the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (helping out) ...tea in China. Oh you're right,  neither would I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps away from NORM and stands near the DIRECTOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traitor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHAKE nods his agreement to this assessment of his charac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this moment JOHN, GEORGE and PAUL enter from the stage door. They are completely unconcerned and walk past the  DIRECTOR, SHAKE and NORM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he passes by) Hi Norm!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (preoccupied) Hi, our lot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOYS walk on when after a moment NORM snaps to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our lot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mildly) Did you want something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beaming with delight) I could eat the lot of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd look gear with an apple in  your gob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (accusingly) Do you realise you could have missed  the final run-through?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh, there's only three of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, we were looking for Ringo. But  we realised he must have come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you realise we are on the air,  live, in front of an audience, in  forty-five minutes and you're one  short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Control yourself or you'll spurt.  He's bound to be somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, let's try the dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone starts along the passage. NORM and PAUL last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh, where's my grandfather?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about him. He can look  after himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, I suppose so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They run after the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here they are, personally signed and  handwritten by your own sweet boys.  The chance of a lifetime. Be the  envy of your less fortunate sisters!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PULLS back and we see GRANDFATHER is surrounde by girls who have broken from the queue and are doing a b trade with the old man. He has a large sign on which is  written: "Get your genuine autographed Beatles photograph On the edge of the crowd two POLICEMEN are trying to forc the girls back into the queue. Finally they wade through girls and confront GRANDFATHER. They look at the old man  quizzically; he stares back coldly. They indicate he shou hop it and quick but GRANDFATHER defiantly glares back at them. So with a sigh, they grab an arm each and escort th old man off.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR POLICE STATION
dialogues.text: It is the reception desk and behind it is the DESK SERGEA After a moment RINGO is dragged in by the POLICEMAN we sa him with before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm Ringo Starr... I've got a  show to do in a few minutes you've  got to let me go... I'm Ringo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, they all say that these days...  Anyway... I don't care who you are...  you can save that for the stipendary.  Here you are, Sarge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reeling off the list) I've got a little list here. Wandering  abroad. Malicious intent. Acting in  a suspicious manner. Conduct liable  to cause a breach of the peace. You  name it, he's done it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, a little savage, is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A proper Aborigine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on his dignity) I demand to see me solicitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well if you're going to get  technical --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment there is a loud series of noises off camer furious shouting and dull crashes of wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, it's going to be one of those  nights, is it? (to policeman) Sit Charley Peace down over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The POLICEMAN takes RINGO to a bench and sits him down as GRANDFATHER and the two POLICEMEN who were with him enter The sign is tattered and is being lugged after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you got me here so do your  worst but I'll take one of you with  me. (kicks the nearest  policeman) Oh, I know your game, get me in the  tiled room and out come the rubber  hoses but I'll defy you still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a fire, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER leans across the desk and hisses at the SERGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ugly, great brute you, you have  sadism stamped all over your bloated  British kisser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go on a hunger strike. I know  your caper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kidney punch and the rabbit-clout. The third degree a the size twelve boot ankle-tap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he on about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squaring up) I'm soldier of the Republic, you'll  need the mahogany truncheon for this  boyo. A nation once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to policemen) Get Lloyd George over there with  that mechanic in the cloth cap while  I sort this lot out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The POLICEMEN hurtle GRANDFATHER firmly but gently over t the bench on which RINGO is sitting and then return to th desk for a whispered conference with the SERGEANT. Meanwh in full conspiratorial fashion GRANDFATHER talks to RINGO out of the side of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ringo, me old scout, they grabbed  yer leg for the iron too, did they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'm not exactly a voluntary  patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shush! Have they roughed you up yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Keep your voice down, this lot'll  paste you, just for the exercise. Oh  they're a desperate crew of drippings  and they've fists like matured hams  for pounding defenceless lads like  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disturbed) Have they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sergeant's a body-blow veteran  if ever I measured one. One of us  has got to escape. I'll get the boys.  Hold on son, I'll be back for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horrified) Me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if they get you on the floor  watch out for your brisket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hopefully) Oh, they seem all right to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what they want you to think.  All coppers are villains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Would you two like a cup of tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, sly villains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (miserable) No thanks, Mr. Sergeant, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We now have a CLOSE SHOT of POLICEMEN around the sergeant desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you just brought the old chap out  of the crowd for his own good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but he insisted on us bringing  him to the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he can't stop here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shot of GRANDFATHER watching POLICEMEN intently and mutte words as he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The POLICEMEN make a move towards GRANDFATHER and RINGO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well son, it's now or never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps to his feet and scurries towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, you paid assassins. Johnny  McCartney'll give you a run for your  threepence ha'penny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dashes out of the door followed by the POLICEMAN who h his pile of photos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, what's he up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's allergic to Bobbies, especially  English Bobbies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The POLICEMAN with the photos returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Irish accent) Your man disappeared like a leveret  over a hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turncoat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The POLICEMEN turn on RINGO and walk towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother!

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR STREET
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER is running at top speed down the street. He i breathing heavily and runs as if pursued by the hounds of hell. The street however is entirely empty and no one is  even in sight. As he reaches the top of the street he pau and turning, looks around him. From his P.O.V. we see jus how empty the street is and heaving a sigh of relief  GRANDFATHER cackles to himself. His triumph is short live At this precise moment down the street comes a parade of  police vehicles, a Black Maria, an escorting police motor bike patrol and an ordinary squad car. The procession dra up and the street is full of policemen getting out of the Black Maria and squad car and off motor bikes. CLOSE-UP  GRANDFATHER's horrified face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be God, they've called up  reinforcements, the dragnet's out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dashes off wildly in the general direction of the thea He has been completely unnoticed by the policemen who are lining up for a last minute inspection by the inspector i charge. The inspector is like a commander-in-chief of a s head attack force. They smartly march off in the direction taken by GRANDFAT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching the clock) Only half an hour and you're on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I say something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The director clutches at any straw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hopefully) Yes, anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (earnestly) It's highly unlikely we'll be on...  I mean the law of averages are against  you and it seems that, etc., etc....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But his speech is drowned by the pitiful moans of the  DIRECTOR.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR T.V. THEATRE STAGE DOOR
dialogues.text: The four little boys from the canal are being driven away the security guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going back into  theatre) I'll have the hides off of you lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids retreat as GRANDFATHER pants into shot, ignoring the kids he enters the stage door but in a second he is o again, grasped firmly by the collar by the security guard

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to be ashamed of yourself.  Go home!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must see Pauly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home then and see him on the telly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GUARD re-enters the stage door. GRANDFATHER looks around him and sees the four kids. He  hustles over and after a whispered conference we hear his offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you fix him for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixpence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER is about to argue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in advance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgusted) Mercenary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he hands over the money. The kids rush in the stage d and after a moment the furious GUARD chases them out and  down the alley. GRANDFATHER, chuckling, nips in the door.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR T.V. CONTROL ROOM ON STAGE
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER is being chased by several studio attendants; is dodging behind equipment. He finally gets on a sound b trolley and uses it as a weapon to keep his pursuers at b

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR T.V. CONTROL ROOM
dialogues.text: The DIRECTOR, BOYS, and NORM and SHAKE see GRANDFATHER on the monitors. They dash out of the room and on to the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) It's all right, leave him alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandad, where's Ringo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police have the poor unfortunate  lad in the Bridewell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be pulp by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAUL, JOHN and GEORGE rush off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've only got twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR STREET OUTSIDE POLICE STATION
dialogues.text: PAUL, JOHN and GEORGE come running down the street in sin file, their knees  high in the air, they skid to a halt a the police station and without pausing they dash inside.  After a moment they reappear -- only this time RINGO is b them. They dash off down the street. They are followed at once by ten POLICEMEN also in single file. They are also pounding along knees high in the air. The BOYS and the coppers disappear around the corner. At  once, they reappear from the other direction, then run do the street still followed by the policemen. When they reach the police station another group of polic bars their way so they are forced to run up the stairs an inside.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR POLICE STATION
dialogues.text: The DESK SERGEANT is standing behind his desk looking ver surprised. At this moment the boys run in and stand panting in front the desk. Before the SERGEANT can start speaking the pursuing POLIC arrive. They, too, are out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heaving and panting) Hold on until we get our breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOYS and POLICEMEN pant on until JOHN seems to have  recovered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. (to boys) Ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOYS nod and without further ado they turn and run th the surprised rank of POLICEMEN and out into the street.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHASE CARRIES ON.
dialogues.text: Shots of BOYS being pursued (still in single file) by pol including the sergeant with one shot where the BOYS are  chasing the POLICEMEN. Finally, as they approach the theatre, they are seen by t girl fans who swarm around the police, over running them. The boys grin to each other and are about to make off whe from their P.O.V. we see the INSPECTOR and POLICEMEN bloc it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah well, it was worth a try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling to Sergeant) What do you think you're up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arrest those boys, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all we need to start a real  riot! (to Boys) Come on lads, they're waiting for  you.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR THEATRE BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: The Inspector now hustles the BOYS through the crowds and through the main entrance of the theatre where SHAKE and  NORM are waiting. NORM looks suspiciously at RINGO who is still wearing his cap. RINGO whips it off and NORM deligh hugs him. The BOYS dash through the stalls entrance and o stage. The DIRECTOR sees them and bursts into tears with  relief. NORM hustles the lads into the wings to be change into their show costumes. All around them last-minute  preparations are going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys, you don't know what this means  to me. If you hadn't come back it  would have been the epilogue or the  news in Welsh for life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you supposed to be in that  box?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DIRECTOR gives NORM a final glare and dashes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And another thing, where's that old  mixer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, Pauly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And sitting on a box sadly chastened sits GRANDFATHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I got a few things to say to  you, two-faced John McCartney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, leave him alone Paul, he's back,  isn't he? And it's not his fault  he's old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hotly) What's old got to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You needn't bother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Practising to be thick-headed, you're  there already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look he's a mixer and a trouble maker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, but he's only asking  us to pay attention to him, aren't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From JOHN's P.O.V. we see GRANDFATHER. He looks what he i a tired old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see. (to Grandad) You know your trouble -- you should  have gone West to America. You'd  have wound up a Senior Citizen of  Boston. As it is you took the wrong  turning and what happened, you're a  lonely old man from Liverpool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fighting back) But I'm clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOYS giggle and slap him on the back.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR TV THEATRE AUDITORIUM
dialogues.text: We see the audience of girls streaming in and settling do in their places for the show. There is the usual business getting the show ready and we see SHOTS of the girls' fac then JOHN, PAUL, RINGO and GEORGE looking at them. At las on cue from the floor manager the BOYS start their act to the audience's screams. During the number we constantly CUT away to the audience  with various SHOTS of the ecstatic girls. In the middle o these shots we see NORM standing at the side of the audie his face glowing with satisfaction. We follow his gaze an from NORM'S P.O.V. we see GRANDFATHER handcuffed to SHAKE but in spite of this, the old man is enjoying himself. The BOYS now perform a medley of numbers, i.e., a little all the songs we have heard during the story. This gives impression of a full set and we finish after their bows.  While they are doing so they look again in the general  direction of SHAKE and GRANDFATHER and from their P.O.V., see SHAKE is beating time to the music but from his wrist dangles an empty set of handcuffs. GRANDFATHER has gone a As the BOYS are reacting to GRANDFATHER's disappearance o again, the trap door on the stage opens and GRANDFATHER  appears in the centre of the group as they finish their a and take their final bows.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR STUDIO CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: NORM is waiting for the boys. With him are two studio  attendants carrying the boys' luggage. As the BOYS excite appear he speaks to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got the stuff. Come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we're not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurries them along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office was on the phone, they  think it'd be better if we pushed  straight to Wolverhampton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight? We can't make it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a midnight matinee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, look here, Norm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you look here, John. I've only  one thing to say to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a swine. So hurry up... we're  travelling!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NORM turns down a side exit where the door is open to the field. In it is an eight-passenger helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR STAGE DOOR T.V. THEATRE
dialogues.text: The BOYS and NORM come out of the building and start to r towards the helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking behind him) Where's my grandfather?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (arriving at helicopter  door) Don't start. Look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys look in the passenger bay and there is GRANDFATH He is still handcuffed to SHAKE but clutching his pile of photos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beckoning them in  with his free hand  which holds the photos) Come on, you're hanging up the parade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys shout "Get rid of those things, etc."

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR FIELD
dialogues.text: The final shot is of the helicopter rising up (SHOT FROM  BELOW). As it disappears, a shower of photos come from it window. We cut to a CLOSE-UP of one signed photo as it hits the g and SUPER the closing credits over it.
